word.description: {雞} is *chicken*, {尾} is *tail*, so {雞尾} is literally *cocktail*. {包} is *bun*, so 雞尾包 is *cocktail bun*.

description: An elongated [bao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baozi) with a buttery shredded coconut filling, the [cocktail bun](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cocktail_bun) was invented in the 1950s as a way to recycle day-old buns by turning them into a “cocktail mix” of fillings for new buns.

word.description:
{腸仔} is *sausage*, and {包} is *bun*, so {腸仔包} is *sausage bun*.

The Chinese for *hot dog* is {熱狗} (yiht gáu), where {熱} is *hot* and {狗} is *dog*.

description: A popular bakery item, [Chinese hot dog buns](https://thewoksoflife.com/2015/03/chinese-hot-dog-buns/) are hot dogs baked in a roll (not fully enclosed like most [bao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baozi)).

word.description: {雪} is *snow*, {山} is *mountain*, and {包} is *bun*, so 雪山包 is *snow mountain bun*.

images.place: Ping Pang Pong, Las Vegas, Nevada

description: Baked [bao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baozi) with a white crisp coating on top, resembling a snow-topped mountain (so it's sometimes listed as *snow-topped bun*). Typically filled with cha siu or something sweet like custard or ([red beans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adzuki_bean)).
